awd_titl_txt: CRII:  SaTC:  Practical Cryptographic Coding Schemes Against Memory Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop practical non-malleable codes, which are encoding schemes that have the property that modifying an encoded message results in either decoding the original message or a totally unrelated message. This will improve upon previous constructions and create practical methods to secure against memory attacks for both computers and portable devices. The practical designs developed in this project would immediately improve the performance in applications that use non-malleable codes. The project introduces new research-integrated courses regarding cryptographic coding and physical attacks, and defines appropriate research activities for training undergraduate and graduate students.
 
This project conducts a comprehensive study of a new cryptographic primitive called l-more extractable hash. The investigators explore methods to derive practical coding schemes using this primitive, and instantiate this primitive efficiently under various computational assumptions. This research is expected to significantly advance the understanding on practical designs of non-malleable codes and their generalizations, and the new developments could potentially lead to many further practical designs against even broader classes of physical attacks.

por.por_cntn:
Non-malleable code is a powerful cryptographic tool to protect implementations against tampering attacks. Despite beautiful theoretical progress, how to design an efficient realization has been a challenging research task.  

To address this issue, this project conducted a systematic study on a new cryptographic primitive -- \ell more extractable hash and it applications to efficient non-malleable cryptography. Particularly, the project proposed this notion and efficient instantiations from different knowledge of exponents assumptions (KEA). Then the project proposed a general framework, showing how to construct efficient non-malleable codes from \ell more extractable hash. This methodology would be important for practical realizations of non-malleable codes and thus can potentially be used to protect against tampering attacks of implementations, in practice. 

In addition to the basic result, the project also explored other algebraic techniques required to analyze efficient lattice-based designs, such as an entropic version of ring learning with errors/rounding problem. This technique was originally intended to perform analyses of the leakage resilience property required by the non-malleable code design, yet later found valuable in many other related cryptographic tasks, such as pseudorandom functions, lattice-based PKE analysis, computational extractors, etc. This exploration has built a solid preliminary for many PIs later work, which is of a significantly larger scope. 

The intellectual merit of this work is the framework and efficient instantiations of \ell more extractable hash, the applications to efficient non-malleable codes, and the algebraic analyses inspired from the research exploration. 

The broader impacts are (1) graduate and undergraduate student training, (2) a new research intensive course, and (3) outreach to middle school students.
